highlights.para: This chapter provides the information you need to start, manage, and end a desktop session.

sect1.title: Starting a Desktop Session
sect1.para: A desktop session occurs between the time you log in to the desktop and the time that you log out. The login screen, displayed by the Login Manager, is your gateway to the desktop. The login screen provides fields for you to enter your user name and password. The Options menu on the login screen lists your login options, for example you can select the language of your session.

You start a desktop session when you log in. The Session Manager starts after the Login Manager authenticates your user name and password. The Session Manager enables you to manage the session. For example, you can save the state of your most recent session and return to that session the next time that you log in. The Session Manager saves and restores the following functions:

listitem.para: The appearance and behavior settings, for example fonts, colors, and mouse settings.

The applications that you were running, for example file manager and text editor windows. You can not save and restore certain types of application with Session Manager. For example, if you start the vi editor from the command line in a terminal window, Session Manager can not restore your editing session.

sect1.title: Session Power Management
sect1.para: This section describes actions that you can perform to minimize power usage during your current session.

sect2.title: To Set a Screensaver
sect2.para:
To set a screensaver, open the Global Menu then choose
Programs Settings Desktop Screensaver .

You can set a screensaver to switch on after a specific period of desktop inactivity. You can open the screensaver with a keyboard action or a mouse action, or you can assign a password to lock the screensaver. You can also instruct the desktop to shut down the monitor after the screensaver starts.

sect1.title: Managing the Session
sect1.para:
You can configure the Session Manager capplet to control the session management of the GNOME desktop. The Session Manager recognizes the following types of application:
Applications that are GNOME compliant. When you save the settings for your session, the Session Manager saves all of the GNOME-compliant applications. If you log out, then log in again, Session Manager automatically starts up the GNOME-compliant applications.
Applications that are not GNOME-compliant. When you save the settings for your session, the Session Manager does not save any applications that are not GNOME compliant. If you log out, then log in again, Session Manager does not start up these applications. You must either use an executable command to restart the applications, or you must instruct Session Manager to use a startup program for each application.

sect2.title: Defining Session Behavior When You Log In and Log Out
sect2.para:
You can use Session Manager to set the session behavior when you log in and log out. For example, you can enable or disable a logout prompt. To open the Session Manager capplet, open the Global Menu then choose
Programs Settings Session Session Properties & Startup Programs .

sect2.title: To Use Startup Programs
sect2.para:
To instruct the Session Manager to use startup programs for applications that are not GNOME compliant, use the Session Manager capplet. Open the Global Menu then choose
Programs Settings Session Session Properties & Startup Programs . You can use the interactive controls in the Startup Programs section to add, edit, and delete programs. If you save your settings and log out, the next time that you log in, the startup programs start the required applications.

sect2.title: To Set Startup Hints
sect2.para:
To instruct the Session Manager to display startup hints when you log in to a session, open the Global Menu then choose
Programs Settings Startup Hint .

sect2.title: To View Session Properties
sect2.para:
To view the properties of the current session, open the Global Menu then choose
Programs Settings Session Session Properties . The Session Properties dialog lists the following:

listitem.para: All GNOME applications that are currently running, that can connect to the Session Manager, and that can save the state of the application.
All capplets that can connect to the Session Manager, and that can save the state of the capplet.

sect2.para: You can use the Session Properties dialog to perform a limited number of actions on the session properties of an application or capplet. For example, you can edit the priority, style, and state of any GNOME application or capplet that is in the list.

sect2.title: To Set Session Properties
sect2.para:
To access the Session Properties dialog open the Global Menu then choose
Programs Settings Session Session Properties .
lists the session properties that you can configure.

entry.para: Use this field to set the priority order for the selected application. The priority order determines the sequence in which the session manager starts applications when you start a GNOME session. An application that is assigned a low priority order is started before an application with a high priority order. The default setting is 50.

note.para: Priority order is intended for advanced users only.

entry.para:
Click on this button to choose a style for the selected application. The style setting determines the restart style of an application. Choose one of the following styles:
Normal
An application that is displayed with a Normal restart style is started automatically when you start a GNOME session. You can use the kill command to close applications with this style during a session.
Respawn
An application that is displayed with a Respawn restart style restarts automatically whenever you close or kill the application. Applications are given this style when the application must run continuously during your GNOME session. To kill an application with a Respawn restart style, select the application then click on the Remove button.
Trash
An application that is displayed with a Trash restart style is not started when you start a GNOME session.
Settings
An application that is displayed with a Settings restart style is started automatically when you start a GNOME session. Applications with this style usually have a low priority order, and store your configuration settings for GNOME and GNOME-compliant applications.

Click on the Remove button to delete the selected application from the list. The application is removed from the session manager, and closed. Removed applications are not started the next time that you log in to start a new GNOME session.
Click on the Try button to temporarily implement the changes you make in this dialog. Changes are not saved until you click on the OK button.
Click on the Revert button to remove any changes you make in this dialog and to return to the last saved settings.
Click on the OK button to implement your changes and to save the settings.
Click on the Cancel button to remove any unsaved changes and to close the Session Properties dialog.
Click on the Help button to display the Session Properties online help.

sect2.title: To Save Session Settings
sect2.para:
To save session settings at any time during a session, open the Global Menu then choose
Programs Settings Session Save Current Session .

sect2.title: To Change to a Different Session
sect2.para: You can use Session Options to manage multiple sessions on GNOME. To change from one session to another you must first save a session with a different name. Once you have saved more than one session, you can change from one session to another.

sect3.title: To Save a Session with a Different Name
sect3.para:
To save a session with a different name, perform the following actions.
Open the Global Menu then choose
Programs Settings Session Session Properties & Startup Programs .
In the Options area, make sure that the Automatically save changes to session option is not selected. If the option is selected, deselect the option, then click on the Try button.
In the Choose Current Session area, click on the Add button.
In the Add a new session dialog, specify a name for the new session and click OK.
In the Session Properties and Startup Programs capplet, click OK.
Open the Global Menu then choose
Programs Settings Session Save Current Session .
The session is saved with the name you specify, and with the current settings.

sect3.title: To Change to a Different Session
sect3.para:
To change to a different session, perform the following actions.
Open the Global Menu then choose
Programs Settings Session Session Properties & Startup Programs .
In the Options area, make sure that the Automatically save changes to session option is not selected. If the option is selected, deselect the option, then click on the Try button.
In the Choose Current Session area, select the session that you want and click OK.
Logout of the desktop without saving the current setup.

sect1.title: Ending a Session
sect1.para: Before you end a desktop session you might want to save your current settings so that you can restore the session later. A dialog asks you if you want to save your current settings during the log out process.

You can end your GNOME desktop session in one of the following ways:

Button
Close down all your currently active processes, then click on the Log Out of GNOME button.
